options.A: migraine patient with daily persistent headache, who used to take daily triptans and NSAIDs, what is the next management step?

male patient presents with headache, congestion, tearing, with a duration of 15-30 minutes, occurring 5 times per day, always on the same side. His history includes pain provoked by touching the face. What is the most likely diagnosis?
pregnant patient presents with a severe migraine attack, similar to her previous migraine attacks. What is the appropriate management?

young female patient, known to have migraine controlled on medications, now presents with unilateral headache associated with lacrimation and conjunctival injection, lasting for less than 2 minutes and resolving completely. It occurs up to 40 times per day, and she is completely asymptomatic between the attacks. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

young lady post uneventful delivery by cesarean section came with a history of positional headache that worsens with standing and improves with lying on her back for more than 2 weeks. MRI of the brain was done (image attached). Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

35-year-old woman presents with a headache, describing 10 episodes a day of sharp pain over the left eye, lasting about 5 minutes each, which cause her to sit or lie quietly until the attacks pass. Which of the following autonomic phenomena is most commonly associated with this type of headache?

question_text: In the same case scenario as above, what is the recommended treatment?

options.A: Carbamazepine

question_text: In a scenario of intracranial hypotension not responding to routine measures, what is the next step?

options.A: Blood patch

question_text: In a scenario of glossopharyngeal neuralgia, what should be done next?

options.A: MRI of the head and neck

question_text: In a case of a headache attributed to trigeminal neuralgia, what is the best treatment option?

options.A: Carbamazepine
male patient reports shock-like electric sensations in half of his face multiple times per day, and he avoids brushing and shaving. What is the likely diagnosis?
10-week pregnant woman presents with severe acute migraine. Which of the following is the recommended first-line treatment?

case scenario of a migraine patient who is doing well and has controlled headaches. He requests a prescription for pregabalin, which he takes occasionally on weekends to help him relax. What should you do?
patient presents with severe periorbital episodic headache lasting 5 minutes. What is the most common associated feature?

question_text: In a scenario of trigeminal neuralgia, what is needed to reach the diagnosis?

options.A: Clinical diagnosis, no need for imaging

question_text: Triptans can be used in patients with which of the following conditions?

options.A: Coronary artery disease
patient has irritable bowel syndrome, is obese, and has migraine. What would you prescribe as a prophylactic agent?
boy presents with a headache that is more pronounced in the morning and is associated with nausea and vomiting. What should be done next?
boy presents with headaches that are worse in the morning and associated with nausea and vomiting. What is the next step in management?
patient with migraine underwent a brain MRI as a routine workup for chronic headache, which showed white matter lesions. What is the most appropriate action?
male patient presents with lacinating pain lasting for seconds, and MRI shows SCA compression over the trigeminal nerve. What is the recommended treatment?

question_text: In the evaluation of a patient suspected of suffering from glossopharyngeal neuralgia, which of the following is important to inquire about?

options.A: Presence of trigger factors
patient experiences a visual aura for 10-20 minutes followed by a headache. What is the most likely diagnosis?
patient has a severe headache with typical migraine features and has had previous episodes during menstruation. What is the most likely diagnosis?

question_text: Patient came with tongue pain and paresthesia, radiating to the neck, increased with neck movement. What is the diagnosis?

options.A: Tongue neck syndrome
